Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: It’s Sunday morning, and my phone buzzes with a message from my mom: “Can you call us today? We miss you.” I glance at the clock—9:30 a.m.—and my church service starts in half an hour. I haven’t spoken to my parents all week, just sent a quick text on Friday, and I know they expect more. They want to hear my voice, to know I’m okay, to feel connected. But I also know how important it is for me to be at church, to worship, to be part of the community that grounds my faith. My pastor always says that being present matters, that we grow together in Christ. I feel the weight of both expectations pressing on me. If I call my parents now, I’ll miss the service. If I go to church, I’ll disappoint them again. My heart aches as I stare at my phone, torn between being a good daughter and a faithful Christian, unsure which call to answer first.
